page.title: 11Memories of old Rawmarsh
page.content: Most houses in the Rawmarsh of the 1920s were 'two up,two down' and in {Pottery Street}there were 4 outside toilets for every 6 houses. Every few weeks a man would empty them and also the{'ash-mid'}- a container for ashes from the fires. At about 2 a.m. a man would come round the streets and wake the miners by tapping on the windows with a pole. Later, another man would come and light the gas lamps. The main streets were{High Street and{Stocks Lane.}Trams ran between them and then on to Kilnhurst Road until 1933 when they were replaced by 'tracklesses' - buses running on electricity. Behind 'Greenfields' there was a pottery factory and there was a fever hospital in Barbers Avenue. Fresh water was available at{Caudle Well.
